fr:title.text: Primal Dual Schema Algorithm for Set Cover

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Primal Dual Schema Algorithm for Set Cover

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Start by initialzing \mathcal {C} = \emptyset and \hat {y}_{ e } = 0 for all e \in U . While there exists an element e \in U such that e is not covered by \mathcal {C} , we let \delta be: \delta = \min _{ e \in S } \left (w(S) - \sum _{ f \in S } \hat {y}_{ f } \right ) We know that w(S) \geq \sum _{ f \in S } \hat {y}_{ f } as \hat {y} is currently a feasible dual solution. Then, we update \hat {y}_{ e } to be: \hat {y}_{ e } = \hat {y}_{ e } + \delta Once all elements of U are covered by \mathcal {C} , we return \mathcal {C} .

fr:title.text: Primal Dual Set Cover computes an f -approximation of an optimal set cover

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Primal Dual Set Cover computes an f -approximation of an optimal set cover

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
f is defined to be the maximum number of sets that an element is contained in. In other words, f = \max _{ e \in U } |\{ S \in \mathcal {S} | e \in S \}| We use primal dual schema to obtain an algorithm for the set cover problem. The primal schema is unchanged. Note that the primal is an ILP, so x_{ S } \in \{ 0,1 \} . If x_{ S } = 1 , then we require the set S to be "tight", that is, it has no remaining capacity. x_{ S } = 0 \text { or } \sum _{ e \in U } y_{ e } \leq w(S) The dual schema is updated as follows: y_{ e } = 0 \text { or } \sum _{ e \in S } x_{ S } \leq f
Note that \sum _{ e \in S } x_{ S } \leq f is always satisfied, since if e occurs in all sets, then x_{ S } = 1 for all S \in \mathcal {S}, but that can only be equal to f as per the definition.

fr:title.text: Primal Dual Schema Algorithm for Set Cover

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Primal Dual Schema Algorithm for Set Cover

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Start by initialzing \mathcal {C} = \emptyset and \hat {y}_{ e } = 0 for all e \in U . While there exists an element e \in U such that e is not covered by \mathcal {C} , we let \delta be: \delta = \min _{ e \in S } \left (w(S) - \sum _{ f \in S } \hat {y}_{ f } \right ) We know that w(S) \geq \sum _{ f \in S } \hat {y}_{ f } as \hat {y} is currently a feasible dual solution. Then, we update \hat {y}_{ e } to be: \hat {y}_{ e } = \hat {y}_{ e } + \delta Once all elements of U are covered by \mathcal {C} , we return \mathcal {C} .
